articles.headline: Searching the Tax Code for Upsides to a Downturn
articles.snippet: Even some tax experts are scratching their heads about how best to approach your 2008 tax bill.
articles.abstract: Even some tax experts are scratching their heads about how best to approach your 2008 tax bill.
articles.lead_paragraph: It’s the time of year when personal finance writers offer suggestions on end-of-the-year tax planning. The problem this year is that there are so many unknowns. Are tax increases in the works? Will you keep your job next year? Will your income drop? And what about all those terrible investment losses?

articles.headline: How India Avoided a Crisis
articles.snippet: In India, banks usually don’t lend money to people who lack the means to pay it back. Any lessons to be learned, class?

articles.headline: Lose Confidence in Your Bank? Turn to the Web
articles.snippet: Burned by their banks, more people seeking help with budgeting, saving and investing are finding help online.
articles.abstract: Burned by their banks, more people seeking help with budgeting, saving and investing are finding help online.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — When the financial sector took a dive this fall, the entrepreneurs behind a new batch of personal finance sites worried that they were in the wrong place at the wrong time.

articles.headline: After Lifeline, Big 3 Are Still in Deep
articles.snippet: Planned changes at G.M. and Chrysler are necessary in the short term, but they offer few fresh ideas, and no company can keep cutting its way to prosperity.
articles.abstract: Planned changes at G.M. and Chrysler are necessary in the short term, but they offer few fresh ideas, and no company can keep cutting its way to prosperity.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT  With a lifeline from the White House, General Motors and Chrysler will survive for the next few months while they revamp.

articles.headline: Handful of Niche Chains Stay Alive in Retailing
articles.snippet: As the retailing landscape deteriorates, niche chains that cater to teenagers and young adults are finding success.
articles.abstract: As the retailing landscape deteriorates, niche chains that cater to teenagers and young adults are finding success.
articles.lead_paragraph: In one of the darkest holiday shopping seasons in decades, perhaps it is fitting that a retailer has been given new life by vampires.

articles.headline: Congo Warlord Linked to Abuses Seeks Bigger Stage
articles.snippet: Gen. Laurent Nkunda, who opposes Congo’s president, has taken the nation to its most dangerous precipice in years.
articles.abstract: Gen. Laurent Nkunda, who opposes Congo’s president, has taken the nation to its most dangerous precipice in years.
articles.lead_paragraph: BUNAGANA, Congo  At the entrance to this bustling border town is a most unusual sight: a speed limit sign. In fresh red, white and blue paint, it is a rare manifestation of order in a nation better known for chaos.

articles.headline: Madoff Scheme Kept Rippling Outward, Across Borders
articles.snippet: Bernard L. Madoff’s fraud, the first worldwide Ponzi scheme, lasted longer, reached wider and cut deeper than anything like it in history.
articles.abstract: Bernard L. Madoff’s fraud, the first worldwide Ponzi scheme, lasted longer, reached wider and cut deeper than anything like it in history.
articles.lead_paragraph: By the end, the world itself was too small to support the vast Ponzi scheme constructed by Bernard L. Madoff.

articles.headline: A Risk for Ford in Shunning Bailout, and Possibly a Reward
articles.snippet: By eschewing any federal assistance, Ford runs the risk of falling behind G.M. and Chrysler.
articles.abstract: By eschewing any federal assistance, Ford runs the risk of falling behind G.M. and Chrysler.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT — The Big Three automakers are now two troubled companies getting government help to survive and one — the Ford Motor Company — trying to make it on its own.

articles.headline: As Outlook Dims, Obama Expands Recovery Plans
articles.snippet: The president-elect’s new goal of creating 3 million jobs would not fully offset the losses of 4 million jobs some economists project.
articles.abstract: The president-elect’s new goal of creating 3 million jobs would not fully offset the losses of 4 million jobs some economists project.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Faced with worsening forecasts for the economy, President-elect Barack Obama is expanding his economic recovery plan and will seek to create or save 3 million jobs in the next two years, up from a goal of 2.5 million jobs set just last month, several advisers to Mr. Obama said Saturday.

articles.headline: White House Philosophy Stoked Mortgage Bonfire
articles.snippet: President Bush, who vowed to spread the dream of homeownership, is leaving office amid a downturn rooted in the housing sector he so ardently championed.
articles.abstract: President Bush, who vowed to spread the dream of homeownership, is leaving office amid a downturn rooted in the housing sector he so ardently championed.
articles.lead_paragraph: “We can put light where there’s darkness, and hope where there’s despondency in this country. And part of it is working together as a nation to encourage folks to own their own home.”  President Bush, Oct. 15, 2002
articles.byline: By Jo Becker, Sheryl Gay Stolberg and Stephen Labaton

articles.headline: At Siemens, Bribery Was Just a Line Item

articles.headline: Just Call This Deal Hoosier Baroque
articles.snippet: Damage from the credit crisis is cropping up in the unlikeliest of places including southern Indiana, where the Hoosier Energy Rural Electric Cooperative is under threat.
articles.abstract: Damage from the credit crisis is cropping up in the unlikeliest of places including southern Indiana, where the Hoosier Energy Rural Electric Cooperative is under threat.
articles.lead_paragraph: COLLATERAL damage from the credit crisis continues to crop up in the most unlikely places. Consider southern Indiana, where the Hoosier Energy Rural Electric Cooperative, serving 800,000 farm, small-business and residential customers, is under threat.

articles.headline: A City That Shopped Till It Dropped

articles.abstract: The people of Emeryville, Calif. are feeling the pain of this disappointing holiday shopping season more acutely than most.

articles.headline: Montel’s Back, and Does He Have a Deal for You
articles.snippet: When Montel Williams promotes products to viewers of “Living Well With Montel,” he has good reason: how much he makes depends on how well he sells.
articles.abstract: When Montel Williams promotes products to viewers of “Living Well With Montel,” he has good reason: how much he makes depends on how well he sells.
articles.lead_paragraph: Although Montel Williams’s talk show was canceled this year, it seemed to have been reincarnated last week at a studio in Fairfield, N.J.

articles.headline: Newspaper Shuns Web, and Thrives
articles.snippet: At a time when most big newspapers are embracing the Internet as their future salvation, a small weekly in New Jersey is shunning it, and thriving.
articles.abstract: At a time when most big newspapers are embracing the Internet as their future salvation, a small weekly in New Jersey is shunning it, and thriving.
articles.lead_paragraph: With 2008 drawing to a brutal close on the media beat  bankruptcies, daily newspapers that are no longer daily, magazines that are downsizing into brochures  a little ray of light appeared in my e-mail inbox. It was from a newspaper owner, of all people.

articles.headline: For Conservative Radio, It’s a New Dawn, Too
articles.snippet: Talk radio hosts are back on offense, with some familiar names joining the airwaves as Barack Obama takes office.
articles.abstract: Talk radio hosts are back on offense, with some familiar names joining the airwaves as Barack Obama takes office.
articles.lead_paragraph: Amid all the pressures on the radio industry, news-talk stations see an opportunity  and his name is Barack Obama.

articles.headline: In Madoff’s Wake, Scrutiny of Accounting Firms
articles.snippet: The big accounting firms are likely to be the targets of investor lawsuits related to the Bernard L. Madoff scandal.
articles.abstract: The big accounting firms are likely to be the targets of investor lawsuits related to the Bernard L. Madoff scandal.
articles.lead_paragraph: As more details unfurl in the Bernard L. Madoff fraud case, so do the lawsuits. And the big accounting firms, which oversaw many of the feeder funds that funneled billions of dollars into what prosecutors describe as the largest Ponzi scheme ever perpetrated, are likely to be among the defendants.
articles.byline: By Michael J. de la Merced

articles.headline: In Zimbabwe, Survival Lies in Scavenging
articles.snippet: Catastrophic agricultural policies and economic collapse have left the country haunted by the half-starved.
articles.abstract: Catastrophic agricultural policies and economic collapse have left the country haunted by the half-starved.
articles.lead_paragraph: NZVERE, Zimbabwe  Along a road in Matabeleland, barefoot children stuff their pockets with corn kernels that have blown off a truck as if the brownish bits, good only for animal feed in normal times, were gold coins.

articles.headline: More Companies Are Cutting Labor Costs Without Layoffs
articles.snippet: More employers are using four-day workweeks and unpaid vacations, along with wage freezes and flexible work schedules.
articles.abstract: More employers are using four-day workweeks and unpaid vacations, along with wage freezes and flexible work schedules.
articles.lead_paragraph: Even as layoffs are reaching historic levels, some employers have found an alternative to slashing their work force. They’re nipping and tucking it instead.

articles.headline: Firm Built on Madoff Ties Faces Tough Questions
articles.snippet: Fairfield Greenwich Group took over $500 million in fees from money it placed with Bernard L. Madoff’s fund.
articles.abstract: Fairfield Greenwich Group took over $500 million in fees from money it placed with Bernard L. Madoff’s fund.
articles.lead_paragraph: Since Bernard L. Madoff was arrested 11 days ago in connection with a $50 billion Ponzi scheme, the Fairfield Greenwich Group has portrayed itself as an unwitting victim of the fraud, the biggest of Mr. Madoff’s many losers.
articles.byline: By Alex Berenson and Eric Konigsberg

articles.headline: Reeling South Carolina City Is a Snapshot of Economic Woes
articles.snippet: Columbia, S.C., has earned the unfortunate distinction of being an economic microcosm, with rising levels of unemployment, fear and desperation.
articles.abstract: Columbia, S.C., has earned the unfortunate distinction of being an economic microcosm, with rising levels of unemployment, fear and desperation.
articles.lead_paragraph: COLUMBIA, S.C.  Even before the job fair opens, the line snakes into the parking lot of the state fairground, a muted parade of lives derailed by layoffs.

articles.headline: Uncertainty Grows Over Parent’s Role in Chrysler
articles.snippet: Chrysler has not said how it plans to use the proceeds of federal loans, but its parent company has indicated it might just give away its 80 percent stake to the U.A.W. and other creditors.
articles.abstract: Chrysler has not said how it plans to use the proceeds of federal loans, but its parent company has indicated it might just give away its 80 percent stake to the U.A.W. and other creditors.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT  Unlike General Motors, Chrysler has provided few specifics on how it plans to overhaul its operations after receiving federal loans.

articles.headline: In Booming Gulf, Some Arab Women Find Freedom in the Skies
articles.snippet: Flight attendants have become the public face of the new mobility for some young Arab women.
articles.abstract: Flight attendants have become the public face of the new mobility for some young Arab women.
articles.lead_paragraph: ABU DHABI, United Arab Emirates — Marwa Abdel Aziz Fathi giggled self-consciously as she looked down at the new wing-shaped brooch on the left breast pocket of her crisp gray uniform, then around the room at the dozens of other Etihad flight attendants all chatting and eating canapés around her.
